awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Exploring the Role of Organics in Atmospheric Contact Nucleation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is focused on the study of a mechanism for the formation of ice particles in mixed phase clouds in the atmosphere.  This mechanism, called contact nucleation, occurs when an ice nucleating particle collides with the surface of a supercooled cloud droplet.  The results of this research will improve the ability to model particles and clouds in the Earth's atmosphere.

The research will test the following hypotheses: (1) Organic particles can act as contact nuclei to promote efflorescence of mixed organic-inorganic aqueous droplets, and the effectiveness of the organic will depend on composition of the aqueous phase; temperature and relative humidity; and composition, oxidation, viscosity, morphology, and size of the contact nuclei; and (2) Organic particles can act as contact nuclei to promote ice nucleation, and the effectiveness of the organic will depend on composition of the aqueous phase; temperature; and composition, oxidation, viscosity, morphology, and size of the contact nuclei. The experiments will be conducted using two complementary levitation techniques that allow freely-floating droplets to undergo single collisions with well-defined contact nuclei: a long working distance optical trap and a dual stage electrodynamic balance.

These studies are expected to provide fundamental data on contact nucleation that currently are not available in the literature. This effort will lead to improved theoretical descriptions of heterogeneous nucleation and enable contact nucleation to be included in atmospheric models that predict the formation of ice particles in the atmosphere.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The physical state, or phase, of tiny particles in the air plays an important role in how our atmosphere works. Aqueous particles, such as salts dissolved in water, grow larger as the air becomes more humid, soaking up moisture from the atmosphere. In contrast, dry, solid salt particles usually remain unchanged until the humidity reaches a certain level known as the deliquescence relative humidity (DRH). At this point, they suddenly absorb water and shift into a liquid state, becoming much larger. When the air dries out again, these particles do not immediately return to a solid state. Instead, they often stay liquid until humidity drops much lower to another critical point called the efflorescence relative humidity (ERH). This delay is known as hysteresis, and it means that particle phase depends on both the current and past humidity levels the particle has experienced.

Why does this matter? Because the size and state of particles influence how much sunlight is scattered (affecting visibility), how easily chemical reactions occur on their surfaces (affecting air chemistry), and how clouds and ice crystals form in the sky.  Despite the importance of particle phase, many computer models that simulate the atmosphere do not fully account for hysteresis, in part because of uncertainties in the efflorescence process.

The efflorescence event back to the solid state is complex to study experimentally or model theoretically because it involves the stochastic process of nucleation.  Here, a microscopic seed of crystal first forms, followed by full crystallization. Our study examined a previously overlooked nucleation mechanism: contact efflorescence, where particles form the tiny solid seed on the surface after colliding with other particles in the air. We found that these collisions can trigger crystallization, suggesting that particles may be solid for a larger part of their atmospheric lifetime than scientists previously believed.

To study contact efflorescence, we developed a new technique using lasers to levitate and hold single droplets in the air indefinitely using an instrument called the long-working distance optical trap. We then collided the levitated droplets with other particles and used spectroscopy and optical imagery to detect when and how they changed phase after a collision.

Our work focused especially on how organic materials affect this process. We discovered that thick, viscous organic coatings can prevent particles from solidifying after contact, while runny, liquid-like coatings do not stop the transition. Interestingly, some organic compounds that have a strong structural similarity to the inorganic components are especially good at triggering the crystallization.

This research helps us to better understand how complex mixtures of particles behave in the atmosphere under different humidity conditions. Beyond atmospheric science, these phase change insights are also useful in areas like industrial crystallization, food science, pharmaceutical manufacturing, and more.
